content.description: Sit start on the crystal face, schlag left to gain the arete, then head over the top.
content.location: From the road, hike uphill a minute through the aspen grove to the small wall with several crack features. Weiner Schlag is the left-most route at this wall on a crystal face that leads to a left-facing arete.

content.description: Sit start with a pleasant hand jam and work your way up the flake to the prominent, suspect block. Bear-hug the large upright boulder atop the suspect block and easily step across it to down climb the large, stemmable crack found on climbers right.
content.location: From the road, hike uphill a minute through the aspen grove to the small wall with several crack features. Swine flu is near the right corner of this wall and can be identified by the left facing hand/fist crack that leads to two large perched boulders at the top out.

content.description: To start, perch yourself upon the small rock at the bottom of the route a hand jam start can be found. Then, work your awkward magic up the short and trickier-than-it-looks finger pod crack. Top out and scramble back down (climbers left). Perhaps if you are tall or have hotdogs for fingers you could just dyno to the top....?
content.location: From the road, hike uphill a minute through the aspen grove to the small wall with several crack features.

content.description: Just left of the Swine Flu high ball, this fun little warm up starts sitting on a layback crack, traverses up and left through great edges and then heads straight up on a slopey sidepull move before finishing on a perfectly sculpted granite sloper. There's a horizontal crack about 10 ft up that serves as the arbitrary finish.
content.location: Right side of Oinker wall, left of swine flu (distinct flake), right of Meat Slurry.

content.description: I've seen this done a several ways... I guess it depends on if you like cracks or holds. The original FA was done by sit-starting with legs in the hole, grabbing the inside rail to start, and jamming your way to the top-out utilizing some interesting face techniques along the way. Alternatively, you can start with legs to the side and hands on the rail, going into a layback technique through the steep arete until the bomber hand jam can be reached. If you feel like a silly send, you can reverse the route and go up through the hole in the back. Pick your own path. Top out and head down the scramble on climbers left.
content.location: From the road, hike uphill a minute through the aspen grove to the small wall with several crack features. Meat slurry can be identified by the in-cut steep start that leads to a hand crack.

content.description: Sit start under the roof using some nice ledges and some "break neck" beta to dive into the fun, easy crack above. Once emerged from the crack at the top, head down (climbers right) on the slab towards a drainage to an easy scramble down.
content.location: From the road, before hiking uphill through the aspen grove, you will see a large, sexy crack through the trees. This is found on climbers right to the other Oinker Wall routes on a nearby formation closer to the road, more amongst the aspen trees.

content.description: A handful of easy boulders, seconds from the road. Great for both the crack and sporty boulderers alike. South facing so gets all day sun in the winter and can easily be walked to even with Iron Mt. Road gate is closed.
